title: Before 1 January 2021, will the Barakah nuclear power plant begin to supply electricity to the United Arab Emirates (UAE) power grid?
preds:
Finally reach the outcome, not sure if the production for Now needed "commercial" power will occur before  the 31st instead of the Probability statement of power to the grid. Inasmuch as the ascension testing is complete and it is providing power to the grip.  First UAE nuclear reactor reaches full power
07 December 2020 Barakah unit 1 has reached 100% power and is now generating 1400 MW of electricity, the Emirates Nuclear Energy Corporation (ENEC) has announced today. The unit, which is operated by Nawah Energy Company (Nawah), is now the single largest power generator in the UAE and is due to begin commercial operations early next year. World Nuclear News, Website. (2020). First UAE nuclear reactor reaches full power. World Nuclear News. New Nuclear. December 07, 2020. Retrieved from
https://www.world-nuclear-news.org/Articles/First-UAE-nuclear-reactor-reaches-full-power Achieving 100% power is one of the final steps of the Power Ascension Testing (PAT) phase of the start-up process for Unit 1. Nawah’s highly skilled and certified nuclear operators will carry out a series of tests before the reactor is safely shut down in preparation for the Check Outage. During this period, the Unit 1 systems will be carefully examined, and any planned or corrective maintenance will be performed to maintain its safety, reliability and efficiency prior to the commencement of commercial operations. Eng. Ali Al Hammadi, Chief Executive Officer of Nawah, said: “This is a key achievement for the UAE, as we safely work through the start-up process for Unit 1 of the Barakah plant. Successfully reaching 100% of the rated power capacity in a safe and controlled manner, undertaken by our highly trained and certified nuclear operators, demonstrates our commitment to safe, secure and sustainable operations as we now advance towards our final maintenance activities and prepare for commercial operations in 2021.” 
UAE achieves 1400MW of Clean Electricity as Barakah Unit 1 reaches 100% Power
07.12.20
https://www.enec.gov.ae/news/latest-news/uae-achieves-1400mw-of-clean-electricity-as-barakah-unit-1-reaches-full-power/
Going with the flow... what a turn of events!
Article indicates "...commercial operations set to begin early next year". https://saudigazette.com.sa/article/601116

The aggregation algorithm, which has obviously been changed by the GJO on demand of a few forecasters, now appears to be overly sensitive.
Compared to what happened to the consensus between yesterday and today, the aggregation - using the former method - would now be at 75% or maybe 80%. I forecast this change in methodology will produce more wild jumps, more pretty bad results on average, and leaves much less room for earning or balancing score.
For the average forecaster, this has now turned a "less-than-zero-sum" game, and it will get ever harder to get your score together.
GJO's bad, this will in the long run make the whole platform more disappointing and less interesting, I fear. Compare this question to ("Tenet")
https://www.gjopen.com/questions/1617-what-will-be-the-total-domestic-box-office-gross-for-tenet-as-of-8-september-2020-according-to-box-office-mojo It took 15 days from 12 to 27 August 2020 after the news broke that Tenet will be screened around labor day unexpectedly to fully incorporate and price in that piece of information. Given the question had almost double the number of forecasters, it should have taken maybe 7 days for this question - not 24 hours. I'm not sure that changing the rules in the middle of a game is such a good idea.
Passage of time update + recent links supplied by other forecasters

https://www.utilities-me.com/news/16379-unit-1-of-barakah-nuclear-energy-plant-reaches-80-power-as-power-ascension-testing-continues >"During the Check Outage, which takes place over a period of several months, Unit 1’s systems will be carefully examined, and any planned or corrective maintenance will be performed to ensure its safety, reliability and security prior to the commencement of commercial operations."

Increasing forecast for now based upon observations from @Wildwood2000. About 5 1/2 weeks until this question's end, with approx. 26 or 27 weekdays remaining (excluding (likely) holidays). https://www.tva.com/newsroom/watts-bar-2-project/watts-bar-unit-2-timeline

Hassan, McLaughlin-Eastham and Essaid (2020). September, 4, stated that: Last month, Unit 1 of the energy plant was successfully connected to the national grid to produce electricity. This is expected to gradually result in the full, commercial operation of Unit 1 later this year (Para 12). “Unit 2 is back-to-back with Unit 1 - it’s in advanced stages of testing & commissioning,” said Al Hammadi. “Unit 3 is also in testing & commissioning, plus Unit 4 just started testing and commissioning” (Para. 13). Reference
Hassan, D., McLaughlin-Eastham, R. & Essaid, S. (2020). UAE’s Barakah Nuclear Energy Plant connects to national grid & accelerates power plans. September 4, 2020. Retrieved from
https://www.euronews.com/2020/09/04/uae-s-barakah-nuclear-energy-plant-connects-to-national-grid-accelerates-power-plans

@fisherdbus and others appear to correct about the ongoing testing process taking "months". I.e.: Likely into 2021 https://www.neimagazine.com/news/newsbarakah-1-reaches-80-power-8369073 https://www.arabnews.com/node/1764836/middle-east https://www.gulftoday.ae/news/2020/11/18/barakah-nuclear-energy-plant-unit-1-reaches-80-per-cent-power-capacity

https://gulfnews.com/uae/korea-uae-energy-sector-takes-cooperation-to-the-next-level-1.1604906379978
Unit 1 is expected to move toward full-power commercial in early 2021.

With the completion of grid synchronization, reactor operators will begin the process of gradually raising Unit 1’s power levels, known as power ascension testing. The testing will be conducted under the oversight of the UAE’s independent nuclear regulator, the Federal Authority for Nuclear Regulation, which has conducted more than 280 inspections since the start of Barakah’s development, according to ENEC.

No forecast change for the moment with conflicting reports about 'readiness' to supply electricity (to the grid). https://www.thenationalnews.com/uae/uae-s-nuclear-plant-ready-to-begin-operations-1.970946 https://www.thenationalnews.com/uae/science/barakah-nuclear-power-plant-s-first-reactor-now-operating-at-50-per-cent-capacity-1.1081771

Nawah Energy Company, the operator and subsidiary of Enec, said tests by an independent body concluded that Unit 1 of Barakah, in Al Dhafra, is ready to generate energy.
https://www.thenational.ae/uae/uae-s-nuclear-plant-ready-to-begin-operations-1.970946
'Hedging' this down slightly for the moment on no definitive indication of when this plant will actually be supplying electricity to the grid

http://wam.ae/en/details/1395302875445
OK...it might happen this year since it is hooked up to the grid. It looks like though they are still getting their ducks in a row. If no news that they are closer by end of month may decrease. Going with the group for now.

Requested clarification and they updated that power ascension testing is considered testing too. I think it was stated somewhere that commercial operation is not planned until next year so the chance that a nuke goes faster than planned seems quite unrealistic.

https://energycentral.com/news/grid-connection-uae%E2%80%99s-barakah-nuclear-power-plant-yet-another-milestone-says-fanr
The plan is late 2020 for Commercial operation.

It's past the testing phase - https://www.power-technology.com/projects/barakah-nuclear-power-plant-abu-dhabi/ and https://www.powermag.com/barakah-nuclear-plant-now-sending-power-to-grid/ https://www.euronews.com/2020/09/04/uae-s-barakah-nuclear-energy-plant-connects-to-national-grid-accelerates-power-plans

Ok...this article says should be commercial by end of year but the question only asks if it has been connected to the grid and it has been! https://www.euronews.com/2020/09/04/uae-s-barakah-nuclear-energy-plant-connects-to-national-grid-accelerates-power-plans

Connected to grid, but is it supplying electricity (beyond testing)? Sounds like PAT testing continues. Not sure how long that takes - have seen references to +1 months.
Full commercial operation is planned by end of year - but has not happened yet. Per question “testing alone would not count”.
“With the integration and connection complete, Unit 1’s nuclear operators will begin the process of gradually raising the power levels, known as Power Ascension Testing, PAT. Throughout this process, the Unit 1 systems follow international best practice to safely progress and test the unit as it proceeds towards full electricity production. Once the process is completed, Unit 1 will deliver, at full capacity, abundant baseload electricity to power the growth and prosperity of the UAE for decades to come.”
According to this it has been connected to the grid today. https://apple.news/A7uAJkPFuR8OOQIUauvZmmg

Plant is now reportedly "connected to the grid". https://www.cnbc.com/2020/08/19/the-uaes-newly-launched-nuclear-power-plant-connects-to-national-grid.html https://oilprice.com/Latest-Energy-News/World-News/Arab-Worlds-First-Nuclear-Plant-Now-On-The-Grid.html

This article says after a couple of weeks of testing it will be connected to the grid. https://constructionreviewonline.com/2020/08/safe-start-up-of-unit-1-of-barakah-nuclear-energy-plant-successfully-achieved/

Criticality was reached 2 days ago. [1] As I wrote in a previous comment, the other two APR-1400 reactors took 12 and 4 months to become operational after reaching criticality. [2] [1] https://www.enec.gov.ae/news/latest-news/safe-start-up-of-unit-1-of-barakah-nuclear-energy-plant-successfully-achieved/
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1083331

Reactor started. Soon it will provide power to grid in a testing phase. To become commercial by end of the year. https://www.thenational.ae/uae/uae-becomes-first-arab-nation-to-produce-nuclear-energy-1.1057355

Little unclear why the percentage chance has risen so much... reaching criticality marks a 4-8 month mark to supplying energy based on prior data (@tmcgraw). 4 months puts us at the beginning of December. There's certainly tons of uncertainty around how the region will react, which might delay putting power out to the grid. Not to mention, there's a pandemic going on. It just seems like there's tons of uncertainty. Most people seemed to be forecasting when his question originally came out that criticality had been achieved in June. This news should suggest everyones original forecasts were far ahead of schedule.

Although the plant has experienced delays they are small compared to other similar reactors and criticality has now been reached meaning remaining hurdles to generate electricity are not highly complex nuclear engineering  ones
(Controlled) Nuclear fission reportedly "has begun" at Barakah plant (unit 1). https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-53619916

I'm forecasting downwards, with part of the idea being that no news is bad news.  There is certainly additional uncertainty in the region that could contribute to this not coming online to keep stability: https://www.aljazeera.com/ajimpact/nuclear-gulf-experts-sound-alarm-uae-nuclear-reactors-200628194524692.html Additionally, there was another post by @tmcgraw that highlighted times of other reactor times to energy output from criticality. His estimate was 8 months (with 4 and 12 being the other examples). Additionally, the feeling that we're in the middle of a pandemic, working on a complicated engineering project, makes this even less likely. Likely to be slowly but surely be revising downwards without any new updates. EDIT: missed the @ sign for @tmcgraw when I first posted this

Unit 1 has been completed since 2018 and fuel assembly loading was completed this March. [1] My understanding is that power ascension testing must be completed before the plant start supplying electricity. [2] The IAEA commissioning guideline for nuclear power plants says that "Successful completion of core physics tests, power ascension tests and other plant acceptance tests may take six months or more from initial core loading and removal of the shutdown guarantee. During this initial period of operation, it is normal practice to plan a short outage (e.g. one month) or multiple short outages to clear all items still unresolved." [3] I'm not clear on what core loading means but I think it's synonymous with fuel loading (could also mean reaching criticality, which hasn't happened yet at Barakah afaik). So 6 months from March (September) would be the minimum amount of time if I understand the terminology correctly. However, if core loading refers to reaching criticality, Barakah likely won't open by 2021 as I can't find a source saying that criticality has been achieved (in May the CEO of ENEC said that criticality was "a couple weeks or a month or so" away). [4] Relevant historical background: there are 2 APR-1400's currently being used, both built by KEPCO (wikipedia lists Shin-Hanul 1 as operational but I don't think this is true, see [6]). [5] It took 12 and 4 months for the plants to open after first reaching criticality. [6] TL;DR: Given that 2021 is 5.5 months away, criticality likely hasn't occurred, and it takes an expected 8 months to open a plant after criticality is reached, I'm not confident Barakah unit 1 will be operational by the deadline. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barakah_nuclear_power_plant
[2] https://atalayar.com/en/content/uae-takes-first-step-towards-launching-first-nuclear-power-plant-arab-world
[3] https://www-pub.iaea.org/MTCD/Publications/PDF/P1742_web.pdf
[4] https://www.spglobal.com/platts/en/market-insights/latest-news/electric-power/050620-uaes-barakah-1-nuclear-reactor-will-reach-criticality-very-soon-official
[5] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/APR-1400
[6] https://pris.iaea.org/PRIS/CountryStatistics/ReactorDetails.aspx?current=886

While the general consensus in terms of the written word is overall positive for the Barakah's opening and use, there appear to be more and more pieces coming out of the middle east that are arguing against the plant, and highlighting why the Barakah plant is wrong for the region.  I've revised my prediction downward, as I am not as confident as I was earlier in the month that this will go through by the end of the year. "One major reason behind the constant warnings is Barakah’s troubling record, which includes more information on the construction and late disclosure of problems emerging in the process. Barakah’s number-three containment building detected cracks in 2017, but this news was disclosed a year later by the Federal Authority for Nuclear Regulation (FANR), which is responsible for the safe operations of the UAE’s nuclear reactors. The authority will now have to be more cautious and bring transparency in its work."
https://newsskill.com/uae-barakah-nuclear-plant-raises-gulf-nuclear-mishaps-risk/ "This is the wrong reactor, in the wrong place, at the wrong time."
https://www.aljazeera.com/ajimpact/nuclear-gulf-experts-sound-alarm-uae-nuclear-reactors-200628194524692.html

An initial forecast with the following key drivers: Contributing:
-Positive developments in fuel loading, testing, and construction gleaned from the sources shared by users on this forum and quick online searches.
-Strong public commitments by key figures in the UAE leadership in support of the project. Detracting:
-Relative inexperience of both UAE and Kepco personnel in the construction and operation of nuclear power plants in the ME
-Potential spoiling by complaints from neighbors (due to a lack of a liability agreement for example)
-Complications in operations due Covid-19 Open to hearing replies with additional information or feedback.
It seems the tests were good, now they need certification to start operations, so I am confident that by year end the plant will start the distribution from the first reactor.

From available information, it would seem almost certain.  However, I'm just sort of a pessimist about big construction projects, especially nuclear plants.  Public statements about project status always seem to be on the very most optimistic edge of reality.  All it would take is one failed test, accident, bad PR, etc, to push the schedule back a few months.

Likely due to increased electricity needs cause by increase stay-at-home activities, and political pressure compounded by recently made statements. Significant risk that rushing might result in faults or issues causing a delay. In addition, the risk retaliation from or targeting by hostile actors is not insignificant.

Going off of what @RRG has mentioned (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1068911) previously, I agree with him, but feel much more confident as there is enough time between now and the cutoff (1/1/2021) that the UAE will be able to negotiate some consensus with their neighbors.

Sources in the question information are pretty good. There are many references noting that the plant is on schedule and should achieve criticality soon.  However, I think there is necessary cautiousness. Major engineering projects, where the company conducting the project is foreign, during a pandemic, seems like a recipe for last minute delays. I have a lot of confidence this will happen soon, but it’s not a given that it will happen this year.
The trajectory suggests testing at the end of the year, but not supply given safety standards needing to be met in advance.

The Barakah nuclear power plant will be a landmark of the Arab world, and an important milestone in the UAE's path towards generating 25% of their total energy requirements in the medium term.  Barakah 1 (1st of the total 4 reactors) has been loaded with fuel and is expected to reach criticality soon. It usually takes between 6 - 9 months from there to grid connection.  So it should be a 70% - 75% chance of Yes (ideally). The reason why I am rolling back to 50% is
- this is the first overseas project for the Korean company behind the plant (KEPCO) 
- would need some sort of consensus among nearby countries (Oman, Saudi Arabia) before going live References:
- https://www.thenational.ae/uae/barakah-nuclear-plant-on-schedule-as-measures-taken-on-covid-19-outbreak-says-enec-ceo-1.1016237
- https://www.spglobal.com/platts/en/market-insights/latest-news/electric-power/050620-uaes-barakah-1-nuclear-reactor-will-reach-criticality-very-soon-official
- https://gulfnews.com/uae/government/uae-mohamed-bin-zayed-visits-barakah-nuclear-power-plant-1.1591900293700
I’ve not read up much on this topic but seems unlikely in the world of isolation in which we now live. Failure of safety measures within nuclear power may contribute as well.

Based on Wildwood’s post. Fuel has been loaded, approval has been given and they are in the advanced stages of unit 1. https://www.power-eng.com/2020/05/07/enec-ceo-addresses-barakah-nuclear-plant-goals-and-schedule/

COVID-19 Won’t Delay Barakah Nuclear Plant, Says ENEC. Utilities. May 10, 2020. Retrieved from
https://www.utilities-me.com/news/15438-covid-19-wont-delay-barakah-nuclear-plant-says-enec

It will depend when they actually achieve criticality , from there it is three months to connect to the grid as we see in Kudankulam or Guangdong

https://energycentral.com/news/uae-crown-prince-hails-%E2%80%98remarkable-progress%E2%80%99-barakah-nuclear-plant
During a tour of the Barakah Nuclear Energy Plant, UAE Crown Prince Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed Al Nahyan hailed the “remarkable progress” being made at the Emirati facility, the first of its kind in the Arab world, and stressed the need to go ahead with the project despite the exceptional circumstances created by the coronavirus. It is being built by a consortium led by the Korea Electric Power Corporation.   KEPCO stock is operating with a negative income of -787,798,000 this quater , with pressure to deliver to its shareholders I think it will motivate KEPCO to complete the project.
https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/015760.KS/financials?p=015760.KS

In 2010, the UAE announced plans to build its first nuclear power plant as part of a new energy strategy to generate 50 percent of its power from renewable sources by 2050. Construction of the Barakah plant began in April 2013. According to an analysis based on data released by the IAEA, the world’s foremost nuclear watchdog, it takes an average of 7.5 years to build a nuclear power plant. Taking this average, we could expect the plant to be finished by September 2020 which gives us a clue to the January 2021 time element contained in the question. [1] Construction, however, was ahead of schedule on the basis of this timeline nearing 94 percent readiness in May 2020 despite numerous delays. The same month, Nawah Energy, the holding company for the Barakah power plant clarified that the coronavirus pandemic had not delayed plans for Unit 1 (of 4) to go online in ‘weeks or months’. Testing on Units 2, 3 and 4 was at 95, 92 and 84 percent respectively at this same time. [2] With COVID cases in the UAE on a downward trajectory, there is some hope that things could be on the mend, with experts predicting a full recovery by 2022. [3][4] Meanwhile, the Dubai Government has announced a three-month suspension of penalties for delayed contracts. With one unit close to operational and even assuming an almost six month delay, I am assigning a 74 percent-”Probable”-rating as a starting forecast. Feedback is always welcome.  [1]http://euanmearns.com/how-long-does-it-take-to-build-a-nuclear-power-plant/
[2]https://www.world-nuclear.org/information-library/country-profiles/countries-t-z/united-arab-emirates.aspx
[3]https://www.doh.gov.ae/covid-19
[4]https://gulfnews.com/your-money/expert-columns/uae-economy-poised-for-full-recovery-in-2022-how-will-this-affect-residents-and-their-spending-1.1590597718841

(Initial forecast:) Per forecaster comments below plus sources listed it currently appears more likely than not that operations may begin by year-end. Testing issues or possibly widespread COVID infections among key personnel could conceivably cause setbacks. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-02-17/atomic-arabia-u-a-e-reactor-passes-final-hurdle-to-startup https://world-nuclear-news.org/Articles/ENEC-CEO-Barakah-to-start-up-very-soon https://www.neimagazine.com/news/newsuae-nuclear-power-plant-to-achieve-criticality-very-soon-7919639 FWIW: Some question the "real" purpose of nuclear in sunny, oil-rich UAE:  https://theconversation.com/why-is-the-uae-where-solar-energy-is-abundant-about-to-open-four-nuclear-reactors-130248#

Although there have been previous delays to this project, the timing from fuel loading to commercial operations judging by the reactors built in Korea ranges from a year to 6 months. Fuel loading was completed on Unit 1 in March of this year (1) which would signal that the plant is nearly ready to go critical, delays tend to happen before fuel is loaded. I am not aware of the fuel from a nuclear reactor ever been removed before operations begin (in a commercial reactor). Although there can be difficulties in connecting the plant to the grid, this is a fairly regular operation and there are Korean engineers there who will have experience of these difficulties.  There are of course, a number of things that can go wrong; coronavirus having an impact on the UAE at a greater level than previously, technical difficulties in connecting the plant to the grid, terrorist attack (<1%), further reservations by the board as to the quality of the training and inspection regime.  1/ https://www.arabianbusiness.com/energy/441903-fuel-loading-completion-marks-uaes-entry-onto-global-nuclear-power-stage
2/ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/APR-1400
3/ https://www.world-nuclear-news.org/Articles/Second-APR-1400-unit-starts-commercial-operation
The nukes ready to go...sanctioned by WANO...geopolitics aside you dont idle a reactor thats met all as builts and safeguards...you pull rods !
All seems to be progressing nicely. High probability they will be adding power to grid prior to the end of the year.
